title: Add type hints for all packages
body:
[Type hints](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/) allow us to perform static type checking, among other things. We could benefit a lot from using them.

[This stackoverflow answer](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32557920/what-are-type-hints-in-python-3-5) does a great job at describing their main benefits.

[pyannotate](https://github.com/dropbox/pyannotate) would come in handy if it had support for py3-style annotations, but meanwhile we can add them manually

[monkeytype](https://engineering.instagram.com/let-your-code-type-hint-itself-introducing-open-source-monkeytype-a855c7284881) may actually be more useful than pyannotate as it generates py3-style annotations

### Definition of done

- type hints for all of `evm`, `p2p`, and `trinity` modules.
- individual `mypy` CI runs for each of these modules using `mypy --follow-imports=silent --ignore-missing-imports --check-untyped-defs --disallow-incomplete-defs -p <module>`

This should not be done as a single pull request, but rather many small ones to iteratively add type hints, slowly expanding the `mypy` coverage as hints are added.
Yes, this looks quite solid.  I'm supportive of adopting this pretty much across the board.

@cburgdorf @HeathNaylor Great to see a collaborative spirit here. @HeathNaylor mind clicking start work [here](https://gitcoin.co/issue/ethereum/py-evm/132) to join @cburgdorf? 

CC @pipermerriam @owocki

I'm gonna echo what I wrote [here](https://github.com/ethereum/py-evm/pull/462#issuecomment-379673580).

In the light of this issue I think it would be helpful if we try to follow the habit that all new code lands with type hints for function signatures right way.

I know there's a bit of controversy around the question whether trivial code needs type hints or not and we haven't set an official rule about this but my *personal* view is that all function signatures should be typed (with the exception of those that are explicitly ignored via special comments because they are too dynamic to type out).

In the long run this would allow us to enable stricter mypy checks (`--disallow-untyped-defs`) that will reject untyped function signatures to land in the code base leaving us with the benefits of a code base that is easier to explore/navigate, enables better IDE support as well as eliminates a whole class of easy to catch bugs.

If we could reach consensus across the team about this we could write it down in the contributing guidelines so that we can refer to that when reviewing PRs.

I agree that we should add type hints to all new code. I have some questions on this though:

- Does this extend to tests?
- Is it ok to not annotate `self`, `cls`, and possibly the return type of `__init__`?
- Is there some kind of canonical style guide for more edge cases like this?

>Does this extend to tests

Been wondering the same. My personal preference is "yes" but I'm ok to have tests be treated as an exception to this rule if there's some pushback on this.

>Is it ok to not annotate `self`, `cls`,

Yes, in fact this is treated as an exception by `mypy` anyway. So even if we use `--disallow-incomplete-defs` (which we do) omitting type annotations for `self` or `cls` is allowed and I believe is the preferred way of writing defs.

>and possibly the return type of `__init__`

That on the other hand does not seem to be possible as `mypy` always expects us to specify the return type for `__init__` as `None` leaving us with an error if we don't

```shell
error: The return type of "__init__" must be None
```

>Is there some kind of canonical style guide for more edge cases like this?

Not really a style guide but the closest thing to that that I'm aware of is the official [Cheat Sheet](http://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/cheat_sheet_py3.html).

Also I consider the [mypy codebase](https://github.com/python/mypy/blob/master/mypy/checkstrformat.py) itself to be a nice reference but keep in mind that the mypy code base is written in a Python 3.5 compatible way which means some of the things can actually be written nicer for projects that do not need to be Python 3.5 compatible (e.g Trinity / P2P)

> Does this extend to tests
>> Been wondering the same. My personal preference is "yes" but I'm ok to have tests be treated as an exception to this rule if there's some pushback on this.

Please let's not do that. Type annotations are mainly useful as documentation and in allowing us to run checks for code that is not tested in an automated fashion, which is not the case for our test functions. Also, pretty much any errors reported by mypy on test code would also cause test failures/errors, making mypy completely redundant there. If there was absolutely no effort involved in adding them and they didn't reduce legibility it'd be a different matter, but that's not the case.
